docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Voters in Okinawa Oppose New U.S. Military Base Okinawans voted against construction of an offshore American military base that Japan and the United States had been planning for more than a year. A3 Koreans Pressure President President Kim Young Sam of South Korea, left, faced growing pressure to yield some authority to his rival, President-elect Kim Dae Jung, before the formal transfer of power on Feb. 25. docs.lead_paragraph: After a two-year investigation of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest insurer, officials in Florida concluded that the company deliberately set out to cheat its customers for more than a decade. ''Prudential trained its agents to mislead, misrepresent and defraud policyholders,'' according to an internal report on the investigation, which was completed earlier this year. The report was obtained by The New York Times late Friday from the Florida attorney general's office.

headline.main: Florida Study Claims That Prudential Cheated Customers

docs.abstract: Internal report on Florida's two-year probe of Prudential Insurance Company of America holds company trained its agents for over 13 years to mislead, misrepresent and defraud policyholders; shows state, which in end reached class-action settlement with company, was prepared to file civil racketeering charges; at issue was practice of persuading customers to use cash value of life insurance policies to buy new policies with greater coverage, with false promise that their premiums would not rise; company denies deception charges; Insurance Comr Bill Nelson comments (M)
docs.snippet: After a two-year investigation of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest insurer, officials in Florida concluded that the company deliberately set out to cheat its customers for more than a decade.    ''Prudential trained...

byline.original: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER and MELODY PETERSEN

docs.lead_paragraph: Adoption decisions should turn on a couple's ability to provide a loving home for a child, not on marital status or sexual orientation. Recognizing this humane principle, New Jersey welfare officials agreed last week to change a rule that impeded adoptions by unmarried couples, including homosexual partners who do not have the choice of marrying. The rule prohibited unmarried couples from adopting a foster child jointly in a single legal proceeding. The new policy will relieve them from having to go through the onerous and expensive process twice, once for each member of the couple. The stupidity of the old policy, which is still in effect in New York and elsewhere, was brought home in October when New Jersey officials prohibited two gay men from jointly adopting their 2-year-old foster child, saying the law required them to go through the proceeding twice. A judge later allowed the joint adoption in the best interest of the child.
docs.abstract: Editorial hails New Jersey policy change allowing joint adoptions by unmarried couples, including homosexual partners, in single legal proceeding (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The New Jersey Legislature's vote to double the cigarette tax to finance charity care is a smokescreen (news article, Dec. 19). Lawmakers disregard census statistics showing that the number of residents without health insurance rose from 13.6 percent in 1994 to 15.5 percent in 1996.
docs.abstract: Janice M Cauwels letter on Dec 19 article scores New Jersey Legislature for voting to double cigarette tax to finance charity medical care (S)
